raw_text:
Verizon 'seals takeover of MCI'
 
 Verizon has won a takeover battle for US phone firm MCI with a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn), reports say.
 
 The two firms are expected to seal the deal on Monday morning, according to news agency reports, despite what was thought to be a higher bid from Qwest. The US telecoms market is consolidating fast, with former long-distance giant AT&T being bought by former subsidiary SBC earlier this year for $16bn. MCI exited bankruptcy in April, having gone bust under previous name WorldCom. The bankruptcy followed its admission in 2002 that it illegally booked expenses and inflated profits.
 
 Shareholders lost about $180bn when the company collapsed, while 20,000 workers lost their jobs. Former Worldcom boss Bernie Ebbers is currently on trial, accused of overseeing an $11bn fraud. Qwest has itself come under suspicion of sub-standard behaviour, paying the Securities and Exchange Commission $250m in October to settle charges that it manipulated its results to keep Wall Street happy.
 
 MCI is the US's second-biggest long distance firm after AT&T. Consolidation in the US telecommunications industry has picked up in the past few months as companies look to cut costs and boost client bases. A merger between MCI and Verizon would be the fifth billion-dollar telecoms deal since October. Last week, SBC Communications agreed to buy its former parent and phone trailblazer AT&T for about $16bn. Buying MCI would give either Qwest or Verizon access to MCI's global network and business-based subscribers. The rationale is similar to the one underpinning SBC's AT&T deal. Verizon is by far the bigger company and has its own successful mobile arm - factors which may have swung the board in its favour since both suitors are offering a mixture of cash and shares.

MCI is the second-largest long distance company in the US after AT&T.
The deal is expected to be finalized on Monday morning.

tinyllama:1.1b: During a takeover battle, Verizon has reportedly won a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn) for US phone firm MCI.
The two firms are expected to merge on Monday morning, according to news reports citing a source close to the deal.
The US telecoms market is consolidating rapidly as companies seek to boost client bases and cut costs.

Former WorldCom boss Bernie Ebbers faces trial for fraud and manipulating financial results, while SBC Communications' proposed acquisition of its former parent and phone trailblazer AT&T has also been subject to scrutiny in the past few months.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The takeover of MCI, a major US phone firm, has been reported to be worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn).
This follows Qwest's bid, which was said to be higher than the one offered by rival Verizon.
Both companies are expected to seal the deal on Monday morning, although reports suggest that MCI might end up selling its shares instead of receiving a cash offer.
The merger would create one of the largest telecoms companies in the world and will have significant implications for the US market.
If completed, it could lead to further consolidation and possibly result in more competitive bidding processes in the future.
This could potentially benefit consumers as it may mean lower prices and more choices for their communication needs.
However, potential shareholders might be concerned about potential losses due to an overly concentrated market.
The decision on whether to accept a bid or sell shares has yet to be made by MCI's shareholders, who are expected to vote on the offer during a special shareholders' meeting in October.
This vote will determine which company gains control of MCI and its $50bn worth of assets.

The deal is part of a wave of consolidation in the US telecom industry, following SBC's $16 billion acquisition of AT&T.
MCI, formerly WorldCom, emerged from bankruptcy in April after a massive accounting scandal that led to shareholder losses of $180 billion and 20,000 job cuts.
Former CEO Bernie Ebbers is on trial for overseeing an $11 billion fraud.
Qwest has also faced scrutiny, settling charges of financial manipulation for $250 million.
The merger with Verizon would be the fifth billion-dollar telecom deal since October, giving Verizon access to MCI’s global network and business clients.

stablelm2:1.6b: Verizon wins takeover of MCI with a $6.8bn bid, expected to be sealed on Monday after a previous Qwest offer.
MCI's collapse resulted from fraudulent accounting practices led by former CEO Bernie Ebbers.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Verizon has agreed to acquire MCI, a US long-distance phone firm, for $6.8 billion, with the deal expected to be finalized on Monday.
This takeover is part of a broader trend of consolidation in the US telecommunications industry, driven by companies seeking cost reduction and expanded client bases.
Formerly known as WorldCom, MCI emerged from bankruptcy in April 2002 after admitting to fraudulent accounting practices that led to a $180 billion loss for shareholders and 20,000 job losses.
Qwest had initially bid higher than Verizon but withdrew its offer.
MCI is the second-largest long-distance provider in the US after AT&T.
The acquisition would grant Verizon access to MCI's extensive global network and business subscribers, positioning it as a significant competitor in the market.
Verizon's larger size and successful mobile division likely swayed the decision in its favor compared to Qwest.
This deal marks the fifth billion-dollar telecoms transaction since October.
